;

;In recent years, county education as a whole has gradually entered the vision of academic researchers, policymakers and the public, and has become an important issue of social concern. The latest hot topic is whether small rural schools should continue to exist and invest resources.

;

;County education is exactly what our Central China Village Governance Research Team partners and I surveyed in counties and townships in many provinces across the country from May 2017 to June 2023. Previously, apart from a few interviews with primary and secondary school teachers, the Huazhong Rural Governance Research Team rarely touched on rural education issues. Until our research expanded to rural governance and rural sociology, rural education became an important part of investigating and writing village governance reports. Around 2017, rural education became an independent research topic, and our research scope expanded from rural areas to the entire county.

;

;In the past few years, our research targets include county and township schools, families, education management departments and grassroots society, trying to analyze a series of emerging phenomena: why the phenomenon of accompanying mothers in county towns is prevalent, and what will happen to them ? What impact do mobile games and online novels have on children in counties and villages? What role does the super high school play in the county? Why have non-teaching tasks in schools increased significantly?

;

;After analyzing these phenomena, we must think about, where is the way out for county and township education? I would like to begin by stating our conclusions. After conducting research in so many places, we have always believed that in the end, it is the county that carries the hope of most children in the county and township.

;

;;A "lose-lose" battle;

;

;Compared with cities, counties are a weak and complex space, which is characterized by weak resources and poor environment in education. complex.

;

;From the perspective of county education, the development status of county high schools is the most important concern for the development of county education. If the county collapses, local people will lose confidence in the area's education, thus accelerating population migration.

;

;The current county is indeed facing a development crisis, and one of the biggest threats comes from "super high schools". Super middle schools rely on their own advantages in running schools to attract high-quality students and teachers from the county.

;

;Some super middle schools will organize preliminary examinations for outstanding students in counties and cities across the province before the high school entrance examination, go to village communities to persuade parents of outstanding students, or entrust some primary and secondary school teachers to serve as students in advance jobs, attracting experienced teachers in the county to leave their jobs through high salaries, etc. The cross-regional enrollment of super middle schools has gradually eroded the basic structure of county middle school student training - the running of schools in county schools has been forced to adopt some short-term strategic behaviors through constant self-exploitation, such as running out of time. Investment, excessive tilting of high-quality resources to a small number of seed players, and even sending students to some well-known high schools for "training".

;

;The choice among these counties is inappropriate and helpless. The helplessness is that the super middle school relies on its multiple advantages to carry out dimensionality reduction attacks on the county. However, this blow has produced a "lose-lose" result: the county is under increasing pressure due to the loss of high-quality resources; the super middle school has become excessively involved due to the gathering of excellent students, and the relationship between students has become tense and psychological problems have arisen. There are more and more students, and the competition pattern has shifted from reasonable scope to competitive polarization.

;

;On the other side of county high school education, the development of county secondary vocational education is also facing many difficulties. On the one hand, the "diversion from general vocational education" policy has increasingly caused anxiety among parents. Most parents generally still cannot accept their children going to secondary vocational schools. In order to avoid falling into the bottom 50% in the high school entrance examination, they try every means to improve their grades. However, for students who go to vocational schools, parents Then there is not much hope for the development of students. On the other hand, secondary vocational schools have poor student training quality due to factors such as weak student foundations, lack of professional teachers, and inadequate facilities and equipment, making it difficult to respond to market demand and social doubts.

;

;Although the state has gradually increased its investment in secondary vocational schools, due to structural difficulties, the development of secondary vocational schools, especially county secondary vocational schools, is struggling. Some secondary vocational schools are struggling to explore amidst the difficulties. The road to survival and development.

;

;;“Cities are crowded and villages are empty”;

;

;In the context of population migration, what kind of education do rural families need?

;

;Looking down from the high school, the development of county junior high schools and primary schools shows two extremes: "cities are crowded and villages are empty". Under the pressure of the government's "education new city" construction and social education competition, the urbanization of education The pace of education is accelerating, and rural students continue to transfer to urban schools. The county has accepted a large number of students from rural areas. However, because the livelihood model of rural families of "part-time work and part-farming" has not changed, and the county cannot handle the daily care tasks of rural students after they go to the city, this task has to be borne by the families themselves. This increases the cost for rural families to study in cities. On the other end of the spectrum, a large number of small rural schools have too few students. It is already difficult to maintain normal student training, and normal interactions among peers cannot be guaranteed. How can we teach and educate people and make adults successful? Moreover, the scattered resource layout has restricted county-level education. The government’s effective integration of county educational resources.

;

;Rural primary and secondary schools not only face the problem of whether and how to integrate resources, but also face the problems caused by the fragmentation of rural families. Problems such as left-behind children, divorce, and "running mothers" have caused a lack of family education for rural teenagers and brought a series of challenges to school education. When schools face children from broken families, they need to spend more time and effort than children from normal families.

;

;Family education is lacking. Schools must first change students’ living habits and then guide students to learn. Due to insufficient family education, the foundation of students in rural primary and secondary schools is weaker than that of urban students, and the number of outstanding students is also smaller. For township junior high schools, a very specific issue worthy of discussion is whether key classes should be allocated. Should education be fair, should there be no discrimination or should students be taught in accordance with their aptitude? If there is no distinction in teaching, and all students are divided into classes in a balanced manner, the few outstanding students in each class may be biased by the underachievers with poor habits; if students are taught in accordance with their aptitude, and students are classified into different types of classes, they may suffer To raise social questions and policy accountability.

;

;Workers in rural primary and secondary schools often have to face such dilemmas.

;

;The school is still a quagmire, and the quaint nature of primary and secondary schools in the county can be seen from the phenomenon of campus bullying. The occurrence of school bullying has the influence of family education, but it is more the result of the interaction of peer groups in the school structure. If the school forms a just order on campus, it can better suppress the occurrence of campus bullying; if the just order of the school breaks down, students can only rely on the self-built jungle order for interpersonal interactions, and the phenomenon of strong bullying of the weak will occur. Unfortunately, a large number of schools are subject to strict restrictions and cannot easily impose some of the deterrent penalties of the past on students who violate regulations and disciplines, making it more difficult to rebuild campus order.

;

;The spread of network technology and the popularization of smartphones have caused serious Internet addiction among rural teenagers, which has further increased the difficulty of education management for front-line education managers in counties. For example, a girl told us that an online novel describing various crimes went viral among her classmates. We checked and found in the relevant comment area that the concepts of "society is a dark forest of conspiracy", "others are hell" and "evil is justified" are quite common among readers of this novel. This book has been banned by the school, but students are still circulating it privately. Even if you don't read it at school, you can't help but take a look when you go home during the holidays.  

;

;Adolescent children have unique spiritual needs at this stage. We found that when children read novels during this period, they are not absorbing knowledge, but looking for themselves and the power to grow. They easily bring themselves and their experiences of real life into the novels they read.

;

;;Upward Hope;

;

;Under the extremely complex educational situation, administrators and front-line teachers of schools at all stages in the county are still working hard to explore and make positive changes . They try to guide, educate and change children from broken families, children who violate the rules, and children who are psychologically fragile. They want to provide a quiet learning environment for rural children, but they are often restrained by rigid rules. In particular, they also need to resist being "sieged" themselves. Various non-teaching jobs squeeze their educational time, forcing them to cry out for "please give teachers a quiet teaching environment."

;

;So far, we have seen more of the embarrassing side of county education, but in front-line surveys we have also seen that county education also has positivity and hope.

;

;In order to race against time and gain study time, some children only give themselves 20 minutes to eat, some carry notebooks with them on the way to eat, and some stay up late to read and work hard day and night. When we look at them with sympathy, they look back with determination.

;

;There are also some teachers who, in order to reduce the negative impact of students’ family factors, often accompany, listen and give them care. Huang Huaju, an outstanding class teacher at Yushan Middle School in Longhui County, Hunan Province, implemented the "accompanying education method" based on the characteristics of rural students. She observed an introverted girl with poor grades and later learned that the student had run away from home due to domestic violence from her mother. Teacher Huang often talks to the girl and invites her to have dinner with her. He expresses his "preference" and helps the girl build her self-confidence in various ways. There are many teachers Huang in rural schools, and they will explore various educational methods that are beneficial to the growth of students.

;

;Some school administrators dare to reform, try to activate teachers and students, and reverse the decline of school development. A township school in Chengdu, Sichuan, once ranked last in the city. The young principal who took office in 2019 reinvigorated the school through reforms, allowing the struggling school to achieve a "turnaround".

;

;There are also rural parents who are working hard to create better educational conditions for their children. When policies fail to respond to demands, they seek change through "self-help". Some people give up their jobs and their original lives and rent a house in the city to accompany them to school. Some people spend huge sums of money to send their children to private schools. They have one thing in common: they try their best to create a better educational environment for their children.

;

;Although there are many development problems in county and township education, although educational resources in counties and townships are more scarce and the situations they face are more complex than in cities, the hope for improvement cannot be dashed. The future development of county education will not only require policy inclinations to make up for the shortcomings of county education development, but also need to activate the existing resources and comparative advantages of county and township schools through system construction to cultivate children's ability to make future choices.

;

;Based on these surveys, we wrote the book "Children of Counties and Townships", which presents the operation of schools, teachers' ideas, parents' demands, students' mentality, policy implementation and other education issues in the form of cases. The frontline situation explores the current situation, problems and future of county education.

;

;;

;

;"Children of Counties and Townships" Yang Hualei and Wanghong are waiting for China Renmin University Press, September 2023;;< /p>;

;In response to the problem, we proposed an education development model for county middle schools, township schools, and village primary schools, believing that the county education system composed of the three is both fair and efficient. Oppose over-investment in small schools and cross-regional enrollment in super middle schools - believing that it is these that create educational competition pressure and national education anxiety. Therefore, we still believe that the hopes of most children in counties and townships will ultimately be carried by the county.
